In this report , we show that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a novel factor in the complicated regulation mechanism of globin genes .

In the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> null mouse , there is a transient effect on the <extra_id_0> embryonic globin genes <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betaH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and a persistent upregulation of the <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> directly regulates and binds to the proximal promoter of <extra_id_0> epsilony gene <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and represses the <extra_id_0> epsilony-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in definitive erythropoiesis .

<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> belongs to group D of the Sox family of proteins that includes <extra_id_0> Sox5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 13 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> 23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 34 ] .
Group D Sox proteins contain a coiled-coiled domain that mediates homo - and heterodimerization [ 6 , 35 ] .

Functionally , dimerization of <extra_id_0> Sox5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been shown to greatly increase the binding efficiency of the <extra_id_0> two Sox proteins <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to DNA that contains adjacent Sox sites [ 6 ] .
In addition , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds more strongly to an HMG-box dimer motif than to a single HMG-box motif [ 5 ] .

Therefore , it appears that target genes for group D Sox proteins , such as <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , probably harbor pairs of HMG binding sites with a configuration compatible with binding of D-Sox protein dimers .

Indeed , in the present study , the defined <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> target sequence of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter contains two Sox / Sox6 consensus sites ( Figure 3A ) .

Functionally , both sites are essential for <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding to the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter and repression of its activity ( Figure 3E and 3F ) .

These observations suggest that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds to this sequence of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter either as a homodimer or as a heterodimer with other Sox proteins .

Because Sox proteins recognize a short 6-bp core - binding sequence that allows for considerable degeneracy , the specificity of their actions is thought to rely upon interactions with other transcription factors [ 36 ] .

In our EMSAs , we had to run the electrophoresis on a 4 % -6 % gel for at least 4-8 h to detect the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - associated band , suggesting that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is part of a high molecular weight complex .

A few other <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> repressors have been reported to bind to DNA sequences near the Sox / Sox6 consensus sites , including the <extra_id_0> DRED <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex [ 37 ] and <extra_id_0> COUP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 38 ] .
<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might interact with <extra_id_0> these factors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and form a large repression complex .

Identification of other components of the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - containing complex associated with the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter will shed light on its mechanism of repression .
Sox proteins bind and bend linear DNA by partial intercalation in the minor groove , and can also bind to four-way junctions [ 2-4 ] .

Therefore , one attractive model to explain how <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins control gene expression is that they function as architectural factors bound to DNA , influencing local chromatin structure by bending DNA and by assembling multiprotein transcriptional complexes .

By changing the local chromatin structure , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could either interfere with binding of other activators to the promoter or facilitate binding of other repressors .
Another example of a repressor that interferes with an activator on the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter is <extra_id_0> DRED <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

<extra_id_0> DRED <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interferes with <extra_id_0> EKLF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , an activator , in binding to the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter [ 39 ] .

Two HMG architectural proteins ( distantly related to the Sox family of transcription factors ) , <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> HMG-Y <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , were demonstrated to bind to the human adult <extra_id_0> beta globin silencers <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> silencers I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> II <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and cause bending of the DNA , facilitating the binding of other repressors [ 40 ] .

<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is temporally and spatially coincident with definitive ( but not primitive ) erythropoiesis ( Figure 6 ) , and <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> represses <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression both in vivo ( Figure 1 ) and in vitro ( Figure 2 ) .

Moreover , in situ hybridization clearly shows that the persistent expression of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in p100H mutant mice is due to defects in the silencing mechanism of definitive erythropoiesis that takes place in the liver ( Figure 5 ) .

Taken together , these data demonstrate that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions in definitive erythropoiesis to silence <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

This demonstrates that ectopic expression of the <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is quite robust in homozygous mutant mice .

The expression levels of two other <extra_id_0> embryonic globin genes <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betah1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) are also higher in p100H homozygotes , compared with WT .

However , unlike <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betah1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> decline in expression by day 18.5 dpc ( Figure 1 ) , suggesting that <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is regulated differently than <extra_id_0> zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betah1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

It is possible that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has a general effect on embryonic globin genes ( and erythrocyte maturation ) in addition to a specific role in silencing <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Although most p100H mutant mice die just after being born , a rare few survive longer .
None have been observed to live longer than 2 wk after birth [ 14 ] .

We examined a single archived sample of liver RNA from a mutant mouse on postnatal day 13.5 for globin gene expression and detected high levels of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in this RNA sample , compared with undetectable <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> RNA in WT control mice .

At this point in development , the levels of <extra_id_0> zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betah1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> RNA were undetectable both in mutant and WT ; however , adult <extra_id_0> beta-like globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> RNA levels were moderately elevated in the mutant RNA compared with WT ( unpublished data ) , similar to what we observe at 18.5 dpc ( Figure 1 ) .

These findings suggest that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> continues to function postnatally to silence <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and has a unique function in the regulation of <extra_id_0> epsilony-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The mechanism by which <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulates the other embryonic globin genes remains to be elucidated .
<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has other effects in erythropoiesis , including a delay in enucleation / maturation in p100H mutant mice .
This may be the result of indirect effects , such as stress - induced proliferation ( resulting from cardiac defects ) and / or anemia .
Severe anemia can lead to rapid premature release of red cells , prior to their complete maturation .

However , the hematocrit of 18.5-dpc mutant mice is only 20 % lower than that of WT ( unpublished data ) , and this mild anemia is probably not sufficient to explain the extent of nucleated red cells .

Alternatively , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> itself may play a role in red cell terminal differentiation , as it has been shown to be an important factor in cardiac [ 15 ] , neuronal [ 10 ] , astrocytic [ 11 ] , and cartilage differentiation programs [ 32 , 41-44 ] .

The restoration of normal enucleation of red cells in <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mouse by postnatal day 10.5 may result from functional compensation of other Sox proteins ( expressed at later developmental stages ) , since functional redundancy is a recurring theme with Sox proteins [ 13 , 45 , 46 ] .
Moreover , erythropoiesis has already shifted from fetal liver to bone marrow by postnatal day 10.5 .
The accompanying change in the microenvironment of red cell production may permit normal enucleation .

Identification of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> downstream target genes and its interacting proteins will shed light on the role of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in red cell terminal differentiation and the enucleation process .

Recently , in vivo and in vitro analyses suggest that reactivation of human <extra_id_0> epsilon-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> would be therapeutically beneficial to adults with sickle cell disease [ 47 ] , providing a rationale for detailed investigations into the molecular basis of <extra_id_0> epsilon-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene silencing .

The present study identifies a novel repressor , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which binds to the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proximal promoter , potentially as part of a larger repression complex .

Because murine <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and its human counterpart are 94 % identical at the amino acid level [ 48 ] , it is possible that human <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may also be important in human <extra_id_0> epsilon globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> silencing .

There is significant sequence homology between the human and mouse <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter regions , and the human promoter contains at least two potential Sox6 binding sites .
Indeed , the existence of a silencer of the human <extra_id_0> epsilon globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene has been proposed [ 49 , 50 ] .

Thus , elucidation of the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> repression mechanism and identification of other components of the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - containing complex may further our understanding of <extra_id_0> epsilon globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulation and potentially reveal additional molecular targets for the treatment of sickle cell anemia and beta thalassemias .
